published_attributes.title: What the heck is an AAR?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
What's an AAR?

Welcome to one of the most useful improvement tools ever - the AAR.

Why it's so relevant? What value does that deliver? What can you actually learn from that? Kamil Puk will answer those questions.

How to best use this course?

In the following steps of the course you'll take a closer look at a number of our exceptional Project Management AARs. Learn from them about project intricacies and the key behaviors in the role of a PM.

Each of the 10 AARs is an invitation to discussion. In the comment section below each case please share your insights.

The best approach to go over this course material is to take it in in 3 to 4 session, going over about 2 articles a week.

Which AAR cases can I expect?

This are the AARs you'll find in the course:

  1. Canvs
  2. Talentspace
  3. Comitas
  4. Grenke 1
  5. Grenke 2
  6. Messeji
  7. Bitvavo
  8. Keto-Mojo
  9. Pomelo
  10. Riide

published_attributes.title: 1. 2020-11-03 AAR Canvs
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Intro/commentary

Canvs is a great case study of project documentation. Hello? Did your client mention they hate rotations? What if it’s not the rotations they hate, it’s the hassle with on/off-boarding? Read how Canvs team created a system that eases onboarding with good project documentation, it’s a short but golden AAR.

➡️ Confluence.

Background story

Canvs is our client since November 2017 and for three years they gave us NPS=10. Recently, something changed and we received NPS=4.

Facts:

💻 the project is team extension and we are having a very good, hard working team: two front-end developers, product designer, QA and PM;

🎤 team’s performance is NOT the issue;

🌪️ we had 6 rotations within a year (3 developers, 2 QAs and AM), client claims that each rotation slows down the velocity and simultaneously costs him a lot of money;

💊 Rotations were diagnosed as client’s biggest pain point and reason for low NPS;

📄 Very poor project documentation;

We can’t force people to stay in the project so we focused our AAR on improving onboarding process.

Lessons learnt:

  1. If you can’t find the right approach for you AAR ask someone for help. In this case, I asked @Kamil Puk for a 15 min call and we brainstormed on the most effective AAR scenarios.
  2. Invite people from the outside to join your AAR. We suffered from the lack of project documentation and asked @Dominika Szenkelbach to join our meeting, so that she (as a member of Quality Tribe responsible for documentation) had a chance to share her knowledge and experience with us.
  3. NPS score - don’t take it personally and teach your team to do the same focus on your goals and action points and on what you can learn from the situation you’re in.
  4. Documentation is not as scary as you may think. After our AAR we realised that:
  • you don’t need a lot of budget and time to built documentation - consistency is the key (for example save one hour every week in your team’s calendars to work on documentation);
  • good documentation = great onboarding;
  • it doesn’t have to be a big file written by the team, if you have a ready sources use them - you can just gather all the necessary links in one doc;

5. Onboarding checklists ✅ may save you the trouble;

6. Measuring happiness index and sharing them with stakeholders is important. I know it seems obvious but thanks to the happiness index I was able to show to the client an impact NPS had on the team. Client was able then to explain his concerns to the team and maintain positive atmosphere in the project.

published_attributes.title: 2. 2020-11-05 Talentspace AAR
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Intro/commentary

By reading 2020-11-05 Talentspace AAR I found the highlight of the lessons learned new and somewhat unique. “If Client says they need a DevOps to improve infrastructure, they may not know that actually they also need a QA to make performance tests later”. It’s an important lesson about how to package and sell our DevOps services sometimes.

➡️ Confluence.

Lessons Learned for Delivery Teams:

  1. Expert Calls at the opp phase are very important. Better matching with Client’s DevOps/QA needs could be made, more questions could be asked. (If Client says he needs a DevOps to improve infrastructure, he may not know that actually he also needs a QA to make performance tests).
  2. Appropriate Handover is crucial! Starting the project without a prepared Kickoff and introduced PM is a very bad practice. It made it extremely hard to build up a relationship with the client.
  3. Assigning both pretty new AM & PM is not a good practice. At least 1 experienced PM or AM should be assigned to the project.
  4. Important agreements with Client should be pointed. If there is flat fee -> AM should ping PMO to have that properly set.
  5. Be more transparent internally and externally. Our team sometimes felt lack of communication from PM of results of important negotiations with Client to them.
  6. Internal PM role might not be clear to the developers. We need to make sure developers understand the difference and we set clear expectations.
  7. Working with Externals (f.e. Tenesys) can be difficult and challenging and our collaboration should be improved.
  8. Netguru should be assertive to defend its interests (Team Happiness here) and sometimes it is needed to terminate a contract not to lose our Talents/prevent burning outs/etc.

Background:

  • Talentspace is Europe’s leading cross-border recruiting online conferences for high potentials.
  • They’re building a platform that integrates all steps and flows for organizing and running career events online. We worked with them in the past (2017). Our current project was pure body leasing team extension.
  • Our team consisted of DevOps, FullStack, Frontend, 1 QA and an Internal PM.

Data (project context)

Budget and days planned (based on the proposal) vs budget and days spent (based on invoices)

Resources:

AAR board: 📷https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_kgOdV4w=/ - Connect to preview

published_attributes.title: 3. 2020-11-17 Comitas AAR
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Intro/commentary

Comitas is an interesting study of assertiveness and being flexible to meet client’s expectations. I find it really valuable that the team reflects on how the level of service they provide saves the day but is not sustainable in the long run for them. Food for thought. It’s short, but don’t rush through reading it, give it some time.

➡️ Confluence.

Lessons learnt for the Delivery team:

  • The fact that Client uses a term, e.g. UX review that among Netgurals is commonly used for one of our processes - this may not be exactly what the Client understands by this term. We should always aim to ask some additional questions to understand the roots of Clients' needs to be able to offer a talent that matches it best hence increasing the chances of successful kick-off and cooperation.
  • Client has gone for holiday right after the kick-off and was unavailable for any calls + replied to emails with a delay. We’ve learned that organising a delivery plan with marking exact points in time we’d need Client’s feedback by worked well. We’ve let them know upfront about the risk that without their input we wouldn’t be able to move forward up to their expectations.
  • We should not let the Client put time pressure on us to an extent they schedule kick-offs when the Team is not yet fully set up. Rush is not the best ally of the quality of services and, in our example, led to a wrong Talent assignment.
  • It is not always the best match to Client’s expectations to use our standard Netguru design process - in this case Client expected many fast iterations and we’ve adapted to it well. That allowed for us to meet Client’s expectations re: UIs. In longer term however it would have been frustrating for the Designer to work in this style. There is no match between our values and Client’s delivery expectations.
  • The cooperation ended naturally with our consent and we believe the timing for it was right - we stepped backward before any major discrepancy of the expectations appeared. Thanks to that we’ve made sure that the Client and the Product Designer will have mostly positive memories of this short but adventurous project.

Background:

  • Client has been referred to us by one of other Clients we’ve been working for a longer time with
  • We’ve initially sold UX reviewer yet in the end it turned out Client wanted us to re-do some of their existing UIs
  • Client had a very limited budget as we have been a 3rd sub-contractor already (Client being the 2nd one outsourcing design this to us)
  • Client is very used to Upwork level of speed and services
  • Client had a huge time pressure due to a deadline he had imposed by his Client. Client had put time pressure on us inviting us to the kick-off himself
  • PM could not have been found that quickly; kick-off happened without the PM
  • During the kick-off it turned our Client did not expect an UX designer but rather an UI designer - UX review was not needed (despite Client used the term UX review at the presales stage)
  • Kick-off hence took place without the PM and the final Product Designer whom we’ve started to look for after the kick-off - then Client left for holiday
  • The new Team needed to obtain all the project/product knowledge from our internal Teams who took part in the kick-off originally as Client has been unavailable for any more calls

That allowed for us to meet Client’s expectations re: UIs. In longer term however it would have been frustrating for the Designer to work in this style. There is no match between our values and Client’s delivery expectations.
  • The cooperation ended naturally with our consent and we believe the timing for it was right - we stepped backward before any major discrepancy of the expectations appeared. Thanks to that we’ve made sure that the Client and the Product Designer will have mostly positive memories of this short but adventurous project.

Background:

  • Client has been referred to us by one of other Clients we’ve been working for a longer time with
  • We’ve initially sold UX reviewer yet in the end it turned out Client wanted us to re-do some of their existing UIs
  • Client had a very limited budget as we have been a 3rd sub-contractor already (Client being the 2nd one outsourcing design this to us)
  • Client is very used to Upwork level of speed and services
  • Client had a huge time pressure due to a deadline he had imposed by his Client. Client had put time pressure on us inviting us to the kick-off himself
  • PM could not have been found that quickly; kick-off happened without the PM
  • During the kick-off it turned our Client did not expect an UX designer but rather an UI designer - UX review was not needed (despite Client used the term UX review at the presales stage)
  • Kick-off hence took place without the PM and the final Product Designer whom we’ve started to look for after the kick-off - then Client left for holiday
  • The new Team needed to obtain all the project/product knowledge from our internal Teams who took part in the kick-off originally as Client has been unavailable for any more calls

blocks.text: Intro/commentary

Comitas is an interesting study of assertiveness and being flexible to meet client’s expectations. I find it really valuable that the team reflects on how the level of service they provide saves the day but is not sustainable in the long run for them. Food for thought. It’s short, but don’t rush through reading it, give it some time.
➡️ Confluence.
Lessons learnt for the Delivery team:

The fact that Client uses a term, e.g. UX review that among Netgurals is commonly used for one of our processes - this may not be exactly what the Client understands by this term. We should always aim to ask some additional questions to understand the roots of Clients' needs to be able to offer a talent that matches it best hence increasing the chances of successful kick-off and cooperation.

Client has gone for holiday right after the kick-off and was unavailable for any calls + replied to emails with a delay. We’ve learned that organising a delivery plan with marking exact points in time we’d need Client’s feedback by worked well. We’ve let them know upfront about the risk that without their input we wouldn’t be able to move forward up to their expectations.

We should not let the Client put time pressure on us to an extent they schedule kick-offs when the Team is not yet fully set up. Rush is not the best ally of the quality of services and, in our example, led to a wrong Talent assignment.

It is not always the best match to Client’s expectations to use our standard Netguru design process - in this case Client expected many fast iterations and we’ve adapted to it well. That allowed for us to meet Client’s expectations re: UIs. 
In longer term however it would have been frustrating for the Designer to work in this style. There is no match between our values and Client’s delivery expectations.

The cooperation ended naturally with our consent and we believe the timing for it was right - we stepped backward before any major discrepancy of the expectations appeared. Thanks to that we’ve made sure that the Client and the Product Designer will have mostly positive memories of this short but adventurous project.
Background:
Client has been referred to us by one of other Clients we’ve been working for a longer time with
We’ve initially sold UX reviewer yet in the end it turned out Client wanted us to re-do some of their existing UIs
Client had a very limited budget as we have been a 3rd sub-contractor already (Client being the 2nd one outsourcing design this to us)
Client is very used to Upwork level of speed and services
Client had a huge time pressure due to a deadline he had imposed by his Client. Client had put time pressure on us inviting us to the kick-off himself
PM could not have been found that quickly; kick-off happened without the PM
During the kick-off it turned our Client did not expect an UX designer but rather an UI designer - UX review was not needed (despite Client used the term UX review at the presales stage)
Kick-off hence took place without the PM and the final Product Designer whom we’ve started to look for after the kick-off - then Client left for holiday
The new Team needed to obtain all the project/product knowledge from our internal Teams who took part in the kick-off originally as Client has been unavailable for any more calls

published_attributes.title: 4. 2020-11-20 Grenke AAR
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Intro/commentary

Finally, 2020-11-20 Grenke AAR is a great case study about fixed price fixed-scope projects. A lot of pressure came from a difference between what was agreed as a scope with the team, and what was in the signed contract . In the end, we finished Phase 1 (design) and resigned from Phase 2 and 3 (development in the exotic stack). I honestly believe that we dodged a bullet, and we could make this decision based on previous learnings from our projects in exotic stacks.

➡️ Confluence.

Key information to give you a bit more context about our Client and project challenges. Details can be found below on our Miro board

GRENKE Polska is a leading brand specializing in IT equipment leasing for small and medium-sized enterprises.

They wanted to build with us a plugin that once installed in the e-commerce store would turn on Grenke Leasing as a payment option + turn on various other functionalities.

The project was divided into three phases:

  1. Phase I: design how the plugin should work and look to meet Clients, Grenke, and Partners (e-commerce stores) expectations
  2. Phase II: build the plugin for Magento platform
  3. Phase III: build the plugin for other e-commerce platforms, e.g. Shopify

Phase I research allowed us to discover that delivery of Phase II will require from 4 to 8 months (depending on the exact scope), while initial estimation included in the contract assumed 1 month.

The complexity of the development has risen significantly and taking into account key risks and lack of internal PHP talent we decided to terminate the collaboration with the Client and resign from Phase II.

Our Lessons Learned for Delivery Teams, Pre-sales, and BD Teams

  • Change of BD representative in the middle of negotiations increases the risk of misunderstanding or loss of information on our side. Good practice would be to make a follow up after a couple of weeks and check the final contract together. In our case, the Client was insisting on adding more and more to the contract and Tomek wasn’t aware that it is extra scope, which wasn’t discussed before.
  • Long contract negotiations can lull vigilance. Also, our MSA is not so suitable for projects similar to Grenke (fixed price, old-style corporation, a lot of extra safety nets required by the Client) what makes the whole negotiation process time-consuming. It turned out to be very frustrating for the Client (feedback mentioned during NPS AAR) and also difficult for us (high legal department and BD representative engagement necessary).
  • Final check if what we agreed on is reflected in the contract is crucial in fixed price/ budget cap project. It allows us to ensure that scope listed is the same as the one that has been estimated by our team. In our case, although we had clear information about necessary re-estimation after Phase II we had more scope listed in the contract than was estimated initially. It led to the Client’s higher expectations in terms of delivery in Phase II within the budget stated in the contract.
  • Product vision was changing during the pre-sales stage because the Client was getting more and more knowledge about possible solutions and functionalities during discussions with us. This is why she switched from a simple plugin to a more complex product and didn’t even notice when it happened. In future projects, we should consider this risk on the pre-sales stage, especially when it's so long and ensure at the end that we are still on the same page in terms of the Client’s current expectations regarding the project and our proposal, contract and estimations.
  • At the end of the day, we resigned from Phase II because we didn’t have the Talent to work on this project internally and we didn’t have enough trust in our external Partner. Contract negotiations and inaccurate estimations were an issue, but not the crucial one for project termination. What is also important is that on the pre-sales stage we had key risks analyzed and addressed, but we didn’t expect that they can shoot up like this.
  • In the future, we should consider if entering this kind of cooperation makes sense for us. In this case, we had and e-commerce project written in PHP and both of these aspects are not Netguru’s area of expertise. Also on top of that, we knew that budget is small and the Client not experienced in software development, not understanding time&material model. All of these aspects should be a red light for us and trigger to question sense of this collaboration taking into account the necessary effort.

Grenke story in a nutshell → Link to miro board

What was important for the client?

  • During Phase I, we need to come up with a set of functionalities that will bring extra value to the plugin so Partners will be willing to install it.
  • The plugin needs to be relatively easily adjustable to other e-commerce platforms (the goal was that after Phase II most of the work done then can be reused).
  • The plugin needs to work on various Magento versions, from 1.9 to the newest ones.
  • They want to start development immediately after Phase I to deliver a solution as soon as possible (best before Christmas).

More background and important facts:

  • Estimation of Phase II prepared by Droptica in June covered only basic plugin while in the contract we had more scope outlined (e.g. mini panel). Phase II has been estimated to take 1 month back then.
  • Droptica and their partner were involved in Phase I almost from the beginning and their first high-level estimation was 2-8 months, the second a bit more detailed 3-6 months and the final one 4-8 months.
  • Adjustment to other e-commerce platforms has been estimated to take around 3-6 months each and covering Magento 2.0 and 1.9 versions +60% each.
  • We consulted estimations with Tomasz Jaśkowiec. His option was that our estimation and approach to architecture does not cover the Client’s key requirements and while the overall estimation seems reasonable, Phase III for each new platform shouldn’t take more than 1 month.
  • Taking into account all of the above - growing estimations and Tomasz’s opinion we decided to not proceed with Phase II. We wouldn’t have any control if the way we build it is the best for the Client. Also, Droptica couldn’t give us any guarantee that estimations will not grow further.
  • Grenke was willing to start the project with us only under the condition that we can take care of everything, both design and development, so our resignation from development is their biggest disappointment in this project what resulted in such a low NPS. However, Sylwia (our main point of contact) highlighted that they are very happy about the results of Phase I.

Also on top of that, we knew that budget is small and the Client not experienced in software development, not understanding time&material model. All of these aspects should be a red light for us and trigger to question sense of this collaboration taking into account the necessary effort.

The plugin needs to work on various Magento versions, from 1.9 to the newest ones.
They want to start development immediately after Phase I to deliver a solution as soon as possible (best before Christmas).
More background and important facts:

Estimation of Phase II prepared by Droptica in June covered only basic plugin while in the contract we had more scope outlined (e.g. mini panel). Phase II has been estimated to take 1 month back then.

Adjustment to other e-commerce platforms has been estimated to take around 3-6 months each and covering Magento 2.0 and 1.9 versions +60% each.

We consulted estimations with Tomasz Jaśkowiec. His option was that our estimation and approach to architecture does not cover the Client’s key requirements and while the overall estimation seems reasonable, Phase III for each new platform shouldn’t take more than 1 month.

published_attributes.title: 5. 2020-10-05 AAR GRENKE
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Intro/commentary

This GRENKE case can be super informative if you want to learn a bit more about a large refactoring, and read some really great tips and tricks regarding working in a long project (team roles!). The team did a great job both in the project and in the AAR. My best takeaway?

Change such as rewriting the app architecture, even if done within a long lasting stable project, should be treated as a separate project with all its aspects: budget, timeline, risks analysis, business value (…)

➡️ Confluence.

Background

GRENKE project was active for over 2 years. We’ve created an application for GRENKE Bank where users could fill in inquiry processes in order to apply for Checking Account or Fixed Loan. This was not a very complex fintech project, done for Finstreet, our long term client.

Whole story started when we planned a whole architecture refactor. This was suggested as the app’s architecture was no longer meeting client’s business need. At the beginning we needed it to be customisable but later on low time of introducing new features became more important (and current app architecture caused new features to be costly and hard to implement).

This is why development team planned new approach to the architecture, and we encouraged the client to perform the full refactor.

Unfortunately before we even had a chance to use all the benefits or refreshed app we were informed that the budget for this project is ending. As this was a long time project and fully managed on Finstreet side - client did not present budget to us, nor did they highlight that risk.

This story may still have a happy end - as in 2021 there might be new budget to continue development, nevertheless we’ve performed an enormous taks of rebuilding whole application based on client’s business value - and we couldn’t use benefits of it as project ended.

Timeline:

Lessons Learned for Delivery Teams

  1. Propose changes based on Business Value - but always keep asking about budget & risks, even if you do not have much project ownership and client does not want to share it.
  2. Change such as rewriting the app architecture, even if done within a long lasting stable project, should be treated as a separate project with all its aspects: budget, timeline, risks analysis, business value. We recommend that AM & PM should plan it and communicate on business level with the client, and some form of kick off to discuss those elements within the whole team (including client) should be scheduled upfront.
  3. When working with non-tech client keep in mind that when client confirms that they’ve received the message it does not mean that they’ve understood what was communicated. When you send a long, tech message that contains a lot of risks and tech assumptions, and you get That’s OK - that should alert you We recommend that you adjust your communication in such cases: use comparisons, metaphors when describing technical aspects, relate to facts and numbers when highlighting technical risks. Propose ready solutions, ask client if they prefer option A or option B, instead of asking an open question (this is also helpful when working with corporate clients who have a long decision loop) Make sure that the message was received and understood - and have it in writing.

published_attributes.title: 6. 2020-10-12 - Messeji re-discovery AAR - a tragedy in three acts
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Intro/commentary

Read it. You’ll see how they used User Story Mapping, and how they could have used it more efficiently, learn why and how they asked more seniorish people in Netguru for support. You can learn about a real estimation technique called 3-point estimation, and jump into one of the best project documentation I’ve ever seen. This project is a true inspiration, and it should be famous!

➡️ Confluence.

Table of contents, a.k.a Lessons learned

  1. Information is power. Without any reliable documents to base ourselves on, we were helpless.
  2. You can’t separate design, tech and business. They all create the product you’re working on and neither one can bring value without the others #cliché
  3. Bring structure to your work as soon as you can. Easy access to up-to-date information empowers both clients and the team - and minimises miscommunication risk.
  4. Having more, but shorter workshop slots allowed for enough time to research, document and prepare for the next day. Made the whole process more productive.
  5. User story map took too much time before the workshop - it was extremely helpful, yet if it had less detail it would’ve also been ok.
  6. Connecting user stories to objectives allowed to always keep business value in mind and not get carried away.
  7. Proper expectations setting and full transparency on business / relationship situation made the team more confident. They had full context and were able to adjust their approach.

The story

In January 2020 I took over a project - Messeji. It’s a web app that was supposed to make sales representatives' lives easier by being a one stop shop for managing all client communications. The designs were done, tested and absolutely beautiful, pixel perfect one might say! Client was happy with the outcome, test users were impressed, investors excited, and I was beyond myself to be working with such a cool product. All left to do was to actually build it, right? Nope. As usual, the devil was in the details.

ACT 1 - Learn what you don’t know

The client decided to do design first for 3 months, then reestimate and start the development phase. Maybe it wasn’t a perfect setup, but hey - it is what it is! We treated it as any other opp, got all of the materials from the previous PM before her offboarding, onboarded presales experts and prepared an estimation. It was packed with AI, ML, 3rd party integrations - that’s what the client wanted after all. We scheduled an expert call to present it and… got grilled. Hard.

Turns out, scope changed in the meanwhile. It wasn’t always reflected on the designs, wasn’t really documented. Some decisions were taken by both the project team and the client, clients' expectations were supposedly communicated, yet… without any paper trail. We failed to estimate what client asked for at some point, but included features that were removed earlier. We were WAY over budget. After a couple of iterations, desperate search for reliable information and some very intense calls, it became clear we have no common ground - it was like we were speaking two completely different languages. We were caught in the he said, she said game and losing client’s trust bit by bit, so we needed to take a step back.

ACT 2 - Talk about goals, not features

It was time to bring out the big guns and put our consulting hats on. We reached out to @Rafał Gawlik and @Mateusz Krawczyński to help us move forward constructively. We knew now the budget was limited and the go-to-market date was getting closer and closer. Next steps became clear: prioritise and plan. Did you ever have this moment when you ask the client about what’s most important for them, and they say EVERYTHING? Yeah. And in our case, they really didn’t know - they just assumed everything is doable, so they wanted it. And we assumed at least 50% of the features don’t make sense, as we didn’t understand why they want to have them. Both NG and Messeji teams got some homework to do.

Netguru

  1. Get the whole project knowledge under control to not have another faux pas.
  2. Prepare a high-level implementation roadmap with different phases.
  3. Dive deeper into architecture and integrations to make future estimates as precise as possible.

Messeji

  1. MVP OKRs - what should the MVP achieve and how do we measure it.
  2. List all the features and prioritize them with MoSCoW.
  3. Score Must have features to determine real priorities.

There were a lot of statements, requirements, documents and research flying around at the time. We needed structure to make sure we don’t get lost again. We created two things:

  • A user story map on Miro, colour-coded according to priorities and tagged to see which objective each US fulfills. It helped us to initially cut scope, assuming that each user story that doesn’t bring us closer to our objectives, is not relevant. They then landed on the bottom of the roadmap, or - as you will - the limbo we didn’t even bother to scope

  • We created a confluence project knowledge base, to gather all up-to-date information on the product, to serve as a single source of truth. We’ve put in place some empty templates on non-functional requirements and tech stack, and prepared a decision log.

For the first time in 1,5 months since the start both me and AM could say we have a full overview and are ready to launch re-discovery with the client

ACT 3 - Get the right people, prepare the right setup and give them the right tools

The client was happy we’re finally treating their needs seriously. We scheduled a series of scoping workshops and onboarded the new team - that, should everything go well, would work on the project as well. And we got straight to work!

Plan:

  1. 2 days for developer onboarding - reading through all the documents, product sessions with me and PD, architecture/infrastructure sessions with others.
  2. 3 days of workshops - 3h in the morning with the client, lunch break and 4h in the afternoon internal for summary, needed research, discussions… Each next day was started with a research summary along with outline of decisions that need to be taken.
  3. 2 days for project reestimation.

Outcome

  • A complete, fairly detailed User Story map, with planned scope for the first 2 releases + backlog limbo, with notes and tags for each User Story

  • Project reestimation, done in 3-point estimate technique. It allowed for more precise tracking and offered more predictability. The team had enough context and information to actually do it well
  • Complete project knowledge base with - what was most appreciated by the team, decision log and architecture outline. Check it out if you’d like https://netguru.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/MESS - we kept it alive as a documentation example

Epilogue

The client was grateful, however the truth was they didn’t have enough budget to spare, nor we were a good fit - and ultimately they moved on to another agency. The product is still not live.

Useful links

  1. 📷Project Documentation - learn more about documentation and find useful templates
  2. User story mapping - what it’s all about, how to do it + templates and examples
  3. 3-point estimate technique - some theory and examples. I have a pretty cool template too, reach out if you’re interested!
  4. Roadmapping tips & tricks

  2. User story mapping - what it’s all about, how to do it + templates and examples
  3. 3-point estimate technique - some theory and examples. I have a pretty cool template too, reach out if you’re interested!
  4. Roadmapping tips & tricks

blocks.text: Intro/commentary

Read it. You’ll see how they used User Story Mapping, and how they could have used it more efficiently, learn why and how they asked more seniorish people in Netguru for support. You can learn about a real estimation technique called 3-point estimation, and jump into one of the best project documentation I’ve ever seen. This project is a true inspiration, and it should be famous!
➡️ Confluence.
Table of contents, a.k.a Lessons learned
Information is power. Without any reliable documents to base ourselves on, we were helpless.
You can’t separate design, tech and business. They all create the product you’re working on and neither one can bring value without the others #cliché
Bring structure to your work as soon as you can. Easy access to up-to-date information empowers both clients and the team - and minimises miscommunication risk.
Having more, but shorter workshop slots allowed for enough time to research, document and prepare for the next day. Made the whole process more productive.
User story map took too much time before the workshop - it was extremely helpful, yet if it had less detail it would’ve also been ok.
Connecting user stories to objectives allowed to always keep business value in mind and not get carried away.
Proper expectations setting and full transparency on business / relationship situation made the team more confident. They had full context and were able to adjust their approach.
The story

In January 2020 I took over a project - Messeji. It’s a web app that was supposed to make sales representatives' lives easier by being a one stop shop for managing all client communications. The designs were done, tested and absolutely beautiful, pixel perfect one might say! Client was happy with the outcome, test users were impressed, investors excited, and I was beyond myself to be working with such a cool product. All left to do was to actually build it, right? Nope. As usual, the devil was in the details.
ACT 1 - Learn what you don’t know

The client decided to do design first for 3 months, then reestimate and start the development phase. Maybe it wasn’t a perfect setup, but hey - it is what it is! We treated it as any other opp, got all of the materials from the previous PM before her offboarding, onboarded presales experts and prepared an estimation. It was packed with AI, ML, 3rd party integrations - that’s what the client wanted after all. We scheduled an expert call to present it and… got grilled. Hard.

Turns out, scope changed in the meanwhile. It wasn’t always reflected on the designs, wasn’t really documented. Some decisions were taken by both the project team and the client, clients' expectations were supposedly communicated, yet… without any paper trail. We failed to estimate what client asked for at some point, but included features that were removed earlier. We were WAY over budget. After a couple of iterations, desperate search for reliable information and some very intense calls, it became clear we have no common ground - it was like we were speaking two completely different languages. We were caught in the he said, she said game and losing client’s trust bit by bit, so we needed to take a step back.
ACT 2 - Talk about goals, not features

It was time to bring out the big guns and put our consulting hats on. We reached out to @Rafał Gawlik and @Mateusz Krawczyński to help us move forward constructively. We knew now the budget was limited and the go-to-market date was getting closer and closer. Next steps became clear: prioritise and plan. Did you ever have this moment when you ask the client about what’s most important for them, and they say EVERYTHING? Yeah. And in our case, they really didn’t know - they just assumed everything is doable, so they wanted it. And we assumed at least 50% of the features don’t make sense, as we didn’t understand why they want to have them. Both NG and Messeji teams got some homework to do.
Netguru
Get the whole project knowledge under control to not have another faux pas.
Prepare a high-level implementation roadmap with different phases.
Dive deeper into architecture and integrations to make future estimates as precise as possible.
Messeji
MVP OKRs - what should the MVP achieve and how do we measure it.
List all the features and prioritize them with MoSCoW.
Score Must have features to determine real priorities.
There were a lot of statements, requirements, documents and research flying around at the time. We needed structure to make sure we don’t get lost again. We created two things:

A user story map on Miro, colour-coded according to priorities and tagged to see which objective each US fulfills. It helped us to initially cut scope, assuming that each user story that doesn’t bring us closer to our objectives, is not relevant. They then landed on the bottom of the roadmap, or - as you will - the limbo we didn’t even bother to scope

We created a confluence project knowledge base, to gather all up-to-date information on the product, to serve as a single source of truth. We’ve put in place some empty templates on non-functional requirements and tech stack, and prepared a decision log.
For the first time in 1,5 months since the start both me and AM could say we have a full overview and are ready to launch re-discovery with the client
ACT 3 - Get the right people, prepare the right setup and give them the right tools

The client was happy we’re finally treating their needs seriously. We scheduled a series of scoping workshops and onboarded the new team - that, should everything go well, would work on the project as well. And we got straight to work!
Plan:
2 days for developer onboarding - reading through all the documents, product sessions with me and PD, architecture/infrastructure sessions with others.

3 days of workshops - 3h in the morning with the client, lunch break and 4h in the afternoon internal for summary, needed research, discussions… Each next day was started with a research summary along with outline of decisions that need to be taken.
2 days for project reestimation.
Outcome
A complete, fairly detailed User Story map, with planned scope for the first 2 releases + backlog limbo, with notes and tags for each User Story
Project reestimation, done in 3-point estimate technique. It allowed for more precise tracking and offered more predictability. The team had enough context and information to actually do it well

Complete project knowledge base with - what was most appreciated by the team, decision log and architecture outline. Check it out if you’d like    https://netguru.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/MESS - we kept it alive as a documentation example
Epilogue
The client was grateful, however the truth was they didn’t have enough budget to spare, nor we were a good fit - and ultimately they moved on to another agency. The product is still not live.
Useful links
📷Project Documentation - learn more about documentation and find useful templates
User story mapping - what it’s all about, how to do it + templates and examples
3-point estimate technique - some theory and examples. I have a pretty cool template too, reach out if you’re interested!
Roadmapping tips & tricks

published_attributes.title: 7. 2020-09-28 Bitvavo#1 AAR
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Intro/commentary

Read Bitvavo#1 AAR for two highlights: client giving misleading feedback, and working with branding. The team learned how to identify when the client’s positive feedback hides an unpleasant surprise later on - there is already a discussion in the comments on how to mitigate it. Join in! I’m quite certain this is a common issue. Also, they share some of their experiences with branding - why they struggled and what they recommend to others. It’s a relatively uncommon service we provide, so this is a rare gem, read it.

➡️ Confluence.

Background

Bitvavo is a project we kicked off on 14-07-2020. Team consisted of 2 Designers, 1 Illustrator and 1 Branding Specialist (added at the end of the project) and PM. The client team consisted of Bitvavo co-founder who was a main point of contact and our decision maker. Client was the product owner.

The Bitvavo platform was launched in 2018, with the goal to bridge the gap between traditional currencies and digital assets. It has become the largest digital assets exchange in Netherlands and one of the leading European cryptocurrency exchanges.

Our goal was to design a friendly yet professional user interface and simplify user experience for the platform so the Client can target becoming a Leader in Europe.

A pivot happened on 21-08-2020 when a Client suddenly shared a a lot of negative feedback and wanted to stop proceeding with the Illustrations.

Lessons Learned 📓

  1. Teamwork • Teamwork makes a dream work. Sometimes to sell one team member ideas we need to use other's authority. Especially if there is a new joiner and the rest of the team had a chance to build trust and relation with the Client.
  2. Feedback • Do not assume that a lot of positive feedback from the Client means that he is really satisfied. Maybe he has a problem with giving negative feedback and it will blow out at some point. Never stop educating the Client that negative feedback is super important if there is any and the sooner we give it the better. Sometimes it may be even helpful to “provoke” Client to give this feedback, only to ensure that what he says about our work is what he really means. • A lot of detailed feedback that does not give a holistic overview of the direction that we should choose should be a warning sign. • If the Client is not able to specify style or after kick-off we discover that style is one the most important aspects for him we should propose workshop or discovery session.
  3. Relations • Relations with the Client built on partnership helps a lot, when we position ourselves as experts that Client can trust it’s easier to recover from difficult situations.
  4. Design process • It's worth to involve experts in a particular area and do not assume that PD and UI expert will do it in the meantime. In our case it was branding. Branding shouldn't be treated as something less important, even on pre-sales stage, dedicated person should be assigned immediately and branding not treated as afterthought. • Don't be afraid to propose completely new approach to the process, even if the Client already resigned from our services (in this case illustrations). We asked the Client to give us last chance and allow to propose completely new approach to illustrations, not taking into account his detailed feedback that he gave before. I worked out. Also when the Client has to detailed vision regarding illustrations and almost draw it for us it should be a warning sign. • It's very helpful when developer is involved in design project so can provide feedback on the regular basis. We were lucky to have this person (Client was also a developer), but in other projects we should always remember about these consultations. • If there is not dedicated person for branding maybe area expert should be consulted.
  5. Presales and Estimations • It pays off when the scope is re-estimated at the very beginning and monitored on the regular basis. Then every decision regarding time (and money) extension is clearly approved by the Client. • Estimations for illustrations should be higher than the ones from pre-sales.

Data (project context)

Budget and days planned (based on the proposal) vs budget and days spent (based on invoices).

Resources

We were using modified sailboat retrospective. Here is a link to the board: https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_kkwedUA=/

Winds

  1. Great atmosphere in the project and perfect teamwork.
  2. We built a good relationship with a client, he trusted us.
  3. Client was always present on meetings.
  4. Gather feedback also in written form, after the meetings.
  5. We managed to set ownership and convince the Client to our approach (Illustrations).

Anchors

  1. Estimation and Assignment process before the project weren't perfect. Branding in the scope - without any booked support from our branding experts.
  2. Too detailed feedback was a bottleneck sometimes - both for us and for the Client (as it turned out later as he didn’t want to spend so much time on it).
  3. Style capturing process was not perfect. Moodboards are just for general impression of style. They are not precise example of chosen style.
  4. Client was afraid of giving negative feedback. We didn't realize that he has trouble saying that he doesn't like something (when it was more complex, like illustrations). He didn’t have troubles with giving feedback regarding UX and UI.

published_attributes.title: 8. 2020-08-18 Keto-Mojo AAR - HIPAA compliancy issue
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Intro/commentary

Finally, you should not miss Keto-Mojo AAR - HIPAA compliancy issue. This AAR might blow you away with its miro board and AAR call structure, which resulted in great depth of insights and action items that span through PMO, Legal, Sales, DevOps, Security and PM teams. Again, we see a great AAR that is facilitated by an external facilitator.

This was a “make it or break it” kind of situation with HIPAA compliancy requirements towards Netguru, which was a huge risk for our project and client relation. We want others to learn from our experiences and hardships so that a company-wide awareness will be spread.

➡️ Confluence.

Who is Keto-Mojo?

Keto-Mojo (https://keto-mojo.com/) is an American company bound with ketogenic diet lifestyle (both fitness and medical benefits). Their main products are blood meters and blood test strips needed for keeping track of blood samples readings (glucose, ketones rates etc). Keto-Mojo Classic mobile app is syncing with meters via Bluetooth and NG-created SDK, making the readings tracking easier, more readable and interactive for the user.

Netguru is re-building and expanding client’s mobile application and backend architecture serving needs of gathering and displaying readings from blood meters.

HIPAA issue (discussion topic) context:

Close to the new backend and mobile app features release, scheduled for beginning of June 2020, we've faced a HIPAA compliancy topic that blocked us for almost 2 months with the launch.

Client provided us months before with development requirements we need to meet, also concerning HIPAA compliancy from the system itself, which were delivery team objectives. Around 20th of May (2 weeks before the initial launch deadline) client forwarded to us BAA documentation, on which based Keto-Mojo required from Netguru to sign that we're HIPAA-compliant company (with trained staff delegated to project + liable to US medical data law. As such signature could be a great risk for Netguru, PM/AM tandem (Dominika&Filip) reached out to legal team to check our options. It became our "make it or break it" situation.

After revising potential scenarios, we've began urgent search for HIPAA-compliant DevOps vendor, who could handle the US infrastructure we've built, and Netguru will own and manage the EU setup only. The situation became a potential relationship emergency issue, where both sides were defending their position - Netguru stated to client at the very beginning we are not a HIPAA compliant company; the client on the other side brought to the discussion a strong point, that Netguru should not promote itself among the US healthcare clients, if the company is not HIPAA-compliant and not ready for such commitment.

Despite a good collaboration along the way and high NPS (9) this was a threat to our relation with client, who already was tired with poor team fits and urgent talent rotations. Client stated even that he feels lied to by Netguru about our skillset ("You should be aware that will happen and it should be NG interest to cover HIPAA topic for your clients' sake").

It took us almost 2 months to close the topic of additional vendor: research, vetting, negotiations, connect client with HIPAA-compliant partner and to facilitate signature of all contracts and agreements between this 3rd party and Keto-Mojo. Without it - we could not launch changes to the US region, which is 80% of Keto-Mojo’s revenue stream.

Feel free to check our Miro board to check all the notes.

Lessons Learned (aka “I will never forget about this again”)

  1. Communication (PM side)
    1. Always follow-up on any discussion regarding security issues, consult and definitely don’t settle on other parties mentioning “We’ve already informed the client” if you don’t have it “on paper”
    2. Escalating HIPAA-related topics as soon as they are appearing
    3. Client communication and HIPAA message available via email or Slack message
  2. AM/BD
    1. I will not only be careful myself with new accounts, but actually will proactively warn NB/EB about such occasions, and hopefully be able to solve their problems like we did with the HIPAA agency here.
  3. Security
    1. I will always warn PM/AM when I see HIPAA or special categories of GDPR data processed in projects
    2. I will always ask PM/AM if they are fully aware of compliance requirements which apply to the products
    3. I will always escalate to my Leader if I see a risk of processing highly confidential data (PCI-DSS, HIPAA, GDPR special categories)
  4. Revision of potential HIPAA topics in any future healthcare projects - takeaway for whole delivery team

Resources:

What we used during our meeting:

  1. Dedicated MIRO board
  2. Maciej’s message to Delivery core members
  3. Data security emergency - case study
  4. Data security issue AAR

Potential risks post-AAR:

  • Actions not taken after the AAR - too many stakeholders/topic owners
  • Change implemented slowly
  • HIPAA compliancy issue not taken care of
  • Multiple similar situations with US/healthcare clients for Netguru (we already hear about some)

How this AAR was prepared?

Requirements for AAR attendees:

  • Familiarize with Keto-Mojo HIPAA topic background (via Miro board+note provided by PM)
  • Prep work before the AAR meeting (notes left in Miro board)
  • Take into consideration already taken steps by @Maciej Markiewicz to make KM HIPAA compliancy topic valuable lesson for us (look at Resources tab below)

AAR Agenda

  1. Short intro - 5min
  2. Revision of notes done in prep work - 5min
  3. Categorization / issue sources grouping - 10min
  4. Action points discussion & AC creation - 30min
  5. Summary and post-AAR plan - 5-10min

blocks.text: Intro/commentary

Finally, you should not miss Keto-Mojo AAR - HIPAA compliancy issue. This AAR might blow you away with its miro board and AAR call structure, which resulted in great depth of insights and action items that span through PMO, Legal, Sales, DevOps, Security and PM teams. Again, we see a great AAR that is facilitated by an external facilitator.

This was a “make it or break it” kind of situation with HIPAA compliancy requirements towards Netguru, which was a huge risk for our project and client relation. We want others to learn from our experiences and hardships so that a company-wide awareness will be spread.
➡️ Confluence.
Who is Keto-Mojo?

Keto-Mojo (https://keto-mojo.com/) is an American company bound with ketogenic diet lifestyle (both fitness and medical benefits). Their main products are blood meters and blood test strips needed for keeping track of blood samples readings (glucose, ketones rates etc). Keto-Mojo Classic mobile app is syncing with meters via Bluetooth and NG-created SDK, making the readings tracking easier, more readable and interactive for the user.
Netguru is re-building and expanding client’s mobile application and backend architecture serving needs of gathering and displaying readings from blood meters.
HIPAA issue (discussion topic) context:
Close to the new backend and mobile app features release, scheduled for beginning of June 2020, we've faced a HIPAA compliancy topic that blocked us for almost 2 months with the launch.

Client provided us months before with development requirements we need to meet, also concerning HIPAA compliancy from the system itself, which were delivery team objectives. Around 20th of May (2 weeks before the initial launch deadline) client forwarded to us BAA documentation, on which based Keto-Mojo required from Netguru to sign that we're HIPAA-compliant company (with trained staff delegated to project + liable to US medical data law. As such signature could be a great risk for Netguru, PM/AM tandem (Dominika&Filip) reached out to legal team to check our options. It became our "make it or break it" situation.

After revising potential scenarios, we've began urgent search for HIPAA-compliant DevOps vendor, who could handle the US infrastructure we've built, and Netguru will own and manage the EU setup only. The situation became a potential relationship emergency issue, where both sides were defending their position - Netguru stated to client at the very beginning we are not a HIPAA compliant company; the client on the other side brought to the discussion a strong point, that Netguru should not promote itself among the US healthcare clients, if the company is not HIPAA-compliant and not ready for such commitment.

Despite a good collaboration along the way and high NPS (9) this was a threat to our relation with client, who already was tired with poor team fits and urgent talent rotations. Client stated even that he feels lied to by Netguru about our skillset ("You should be aware that will happen and it should be NG interest to cover HIPAA topic for your clients' sake").

It took us almost 2 months to close the topic of additional vendor: research, vetting, negotiations, connect client with HIPAA-compliant partner and to facilitate signature of all contracts and agreements between this 3rd party and Keto-Mojo. Communication (PM side)
Always follow-up on any discussion regarding security issues, consult and definitely don’t settle on other parties mentioning “We’ve already informed the client” if you don’t have it “on paper”
Escalating HIPAA-related topics as soon as they are appearing

AM/BD

I will not only be careful myself with new accounts, but actually will proactively warn NB/EB about such occasions, and hopefully be able to solve their problems like we did with the HIPAA agency here.
Security
I will always warn PM/AM when I see HIPAA or special categories of GDPR data processed in projects
I will always ask PM/AM if they are fully aware of compliance requirements which apply to the products
I will always escalate to my Leader if I see a risk of processing highly confidential data (PCI-DSS, HIPAA, GDPR special categories)
Revision of potential HIPAA topics in any future healthcare projects - takeaway for whole delivery team

What we used during our meeting:
Dedicated MIRO board
Maciej’s message to Delivery core members
Data security emergency - case study
Data security issue AAR
Potential risks post-AAR:
Actions not taken after the AAR - too many stakeholders/topic owners
Change implemented slowly
HIPAA compliancy issue not taken care of
Multiple similar situations with US/healthcare clients for Netguru (we already hear about some)
How this AAR was prepared?
Requirements for AAR attendees:
Familiarize with Keto-Mojo HIPAA topic background (via Miro board+note provided by PM)
Prep work before the AAR meeting (notes left in Miro board)
Take into consideration already taken steps by @Maciej Markiewicz to make KM HIPAA compliancy topic valuable lesson for us (look at Resources tab below)
AAR Agenda
Short intro - 5min
Revision of notes done in prep work - 5min
Categorization / issue sources grouping - 10min
Action points discussion & AC creation - 30min

published_attributes.title: 9. 2020-07-07 Pomelo 🍊 AAR - End of Design Project
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Intro/commentary

Pomelo - it’s great to see the clear division between Lessons Learned and Action Points here. It’s one of the most readable reports I’ve ever seen This outcome is a result of a simple but powerful “We imagined that the project was starting again and focused on identifying the things we would do differently now that we had the experience behind us”. Dive into Lessons Learned to read about Figma, and the synergy between user testing and identifying Business Value.

➡️ Confluence.

Background 🔰

Pomelo was a project where we worked with the co-founders to design the MVP of their first fintech app. This is an app which lets people from USA manage and support the finances of their loved ones back in Philippines.

We started by looking for the business value for the founders and creating the first wireframes based on them. We continued by validating the wireframes with the stakeholders and started working on the app UI. Finally, the client asked us to make a prototype so that it would be easier for them to share the app with potential partners and supporting banks.

Generally the cooperation was really pleasant for the whole team with good feedback and expectations met by the client.

Important Details:

  • This was a Figma only project.
  • Working with startup, we ideated the app with them.
  • One Designer.
  • We were working with Jira Next-Gen with good results.

Lessons Learned 📓

  1. Figma • is a very useful tool for design projects. We managed to keep everything there and conducted our meetings with the client by walking through the designs.
  2. Business Value • we learned how important it is to discuss and seek the Business Value of any project in order to avoid making incorrect assumptions and to find the exact benefit we can bring as Netguru to the table.
  3. User Testing • the role and benefit of user testing in a design project needs to be identified early on. We spent almost a week on creating tests which ended up not being used as we wanted, due to the fact that they did not bring as much value to the project as there were not many people available to test the app.
  4. Clickable Prototypes • creating an interactive prototype early on was very useful for the project. We managed to identify with the client some gaps in the user flows that may have not been found in another way. Additionally, having a design that clients could play with brought a swarm of very valuable feedback to the team.

Retrospective 🕵️‍♀️

During the AAR meeting with the team, we tried to use a new format of conducting these meetings. We had a feeling that the project went very well with a pleasant cooperation behind us. In order to bring the most value to this meeting we decided to focus only on one topic. We imagined that the project was starting again and focused on identifying the things we would do differently now that we had the experience behind us.

Check out our answers to the question below 👇

If the project started again today, what would you have done differently?

  1. We would not push for the Case Study publication so much. The client wanted a discount in order to let us publish, but in fact already agreed on it before the project started by signing the MSA.
  2. We would re-evaluate the User Testing in order to bring better value to the project. User Testing did not bring a lot of value for us or the client and we spent almost a week working on it. We were expected to create the user tests and the client would provide the testers, this did not work out as the client failed to provide the right people in order to bring value.
  3. We would take time early to identify and clarify the Business Value of a project in order to be sure to focus on valuable work. Notes from Team:
    1. Maybe, in the beginning, we could be more transparent with the up-sell that we tried to do later in the project. For example, we didn't predict that the brand might need additional branding exercises and illustrations. Maybe if we could ask about it directly at the beginning of the project that the client would be more convinced to do it. Also, this would help to better coordinate with the project timeline.
    2. Would have talked about business value much earlier in the project. We had a few assumptions that were proven wrong later on in the project.
    3. We only realised towards the end of the project that Prototypes are more important to them than a design system.
    4. I would approach the topic of branding more specifically. We have spent quite some time on prep calls etc, whereas in retrospective it seems that the Client was almost sure he will not be willing to work this part of the project out with us.
  4. AM would spend more time for a 'creative approach' towards the Client in terms of NG's engagement.
  5. We would not push the client to comment on Figma for feedback, having daily calls gave us a lot of data to work with either way. Commenting in Figma did not always work with the clients. We had a few moments when we were waiting for them to reply to us if we were going in the right direction. Talking about these ideas in the calls was more useful.
  6. PM would not suggest to work on the illustrations ourselves, seeing how good was the work of their illustrator from Philippines.

One More Thing 🤘

The client is coming back to us to work on their Landing Page and the Netguru expert call will happen really soon

Background 🔰

Pomelo was a project where we worked with the co-founders to design the MVP of their first fintech app. This is an app which lets people from USA manage and support the finances of their loved ones back in Philippines.

We started by looking for the business value for the founders and creating the first wireframes based on them. We continued by validating the wireframes with the stakeholders and started working on the app UI. Finally, the client asked us to make a prototype so that it would be  easier for them to share the app with potential partners and supporting banks.
Generally the cooperation was really pleasant for the whole team with good feedback and expectations met by the client.
Important Details:
This was a Figma only project.
Working with startup, we ideated the app with them.
One Designer.
We were working with Jira Next-Gen with good results.
Lessons Learned 📓
Figma • is a very useful tool for design projects. We managed to keep everything there and conducted our meetings with the client by walking through the designs.

Business Value • we learned how important it is to discuss and seek the Business Value of any project in order to avoid making incorrect assumptions and to find the exact benefit we can bring as Netguru to the table.

User Testing • the role and benefit of user testing in a design project needs to be identified early on. We spent almost a week on creating tests which ended up not being used as we wanted, due to the fact that they did not bring as much value to the project as there were not many people available to test the app.

Clickable Prototypes • creating an interactive prototype early on was very useful for the project. We managed to identify with the client some gaps in the user flows that may have not been found in another way. Additionally, having a design that clients could play with brought a swarm of very valuable feedback to the team.
Retrospective 🕵️‍♀️

During the AAR meeting with the team, we tried to use a new format of conducting these meetings. We had a feeling that the project went very well with a pleasant cooperation behind us. In order to bring the most value to this meeting we decided to focus only on one topic. We imagined that the project was starting again and focused on identifying the things we would do differently now that we had the experience behind us.
Check out our answers to the question below 👇
If the project started again today, what would you have done differently?
We would not push for the Case Study publication so much. The client wanted a discount in order to let us publish, but in fact already agreed on it before the project started by signing the MSA.

We would re-evaluate the User Testing in order to bring better value to the project. User Testing did not bring a lot of value for us or the client and we spent almost a week working on it. We were expected to create the user tests and the client would provide the testers, this did not work out as the client failed to provide the right people in order to bring value.

We would take time early to identify and clarify the Business Value of a project in order to be sure to focus on valuable work. 
Notes from Team:

Maybe, in the beginning, we could be more transparent with the up-sell that we tried to do later in the project. For example, we didn't predict that the brand might need additional branding exercises and illustrations. Maybe if we could ask about it directly at the beginning of the project that the client would be more convinced to do it. Also, this would help to better coordinate with the project timeline.
Would have talked about business value much earlier in the project. We had a few assumptions that were proven wrong later on in the project.
We only realised towards the end of the project that Prototypes are more important to them than a design system.

I would approach the topic of branding more specifically. We have spent quite some time on prep calls etc, whereas in retrospective it seems that the Client was almost sure he will not be willing to work this part of the project out with us.
AM would spend more time for a 'creative approach' towards the Client in terms of NG's engagement.

We would not push the client to comment on Figma for feedback, having daily calls gave us a lot of data to work with either way. Commenting in Figma did not always work with the clients. We had a few moments when we were waiting for them to reply to us if we were going in the right direction. Talking about these ideas in the calls was more useful.
PM would not suggest to work on the illustrations ourselves, seeing how good was the work of their illustrator from Philippines.
One More Thing 🤘
The client is coming back to us to work on their Landing Page and the Netguru expert call will happen really soon

published_attributes.title: 10. 2020-07-23 Riide AAR
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Intro/commentary

Riide is a great example of what we can when the usual facilitator - the PM - feels they are too emotionally invested to be an unbiased meeting leader. This intra-project AAR was facilitated by a peer PM It allows the full team to keep their eyes on a day-to-day operations while someone else prepares, facilitates, and documents the AAR. Great teamwork!

➡️ Confluence.

Background

In July 2019 we started our cooperation with Riide working on their mobile apps on iOS and Android.

In December 2019 we kicked off the side project named Riide for Business (RfB) - an additional assignment for React FE dev was added, PM engagement grew in order to help with PO responsibilities, QA assignments were terminated.

Backend is shared for Riide apps and RfB but is developed by another agency that Riide works with.

After a couple of months of development it turned out that we are very far from going live with the RfB webapp even though almost whole planned scope was delivered - once the client ran some in-depth testing of the whole application it turned out that the majority of features were not working as expected, the app felt clunky and a lot of bugs were spotted. The client felt extremely worried about the progress.

We added an additional frontend developer, QA, involved N-Force and Discovery team members with some extra support from PM’s leader in order to meet the deadline set.

AAR Board

Key findings

Communication

  1. The requirements for Riide for Business' overall scope were presented in not very clear way, backend team was not included until there were specific changes requested from them which resulted in the lack of total understanding and alignment between teams (NG, backend, Client) - even now some issues need clarification.
  2. Communication between backend and frontend was mostly asynchronous which caused delays.
  3. There is no single document including all decisions made as the project continues.
  4. Questions about expectations, budget and deadline for the project were not asked at the beginning and there was no tracking of overall progress and budget in the project.
  5. There was no risk analysis created for Riide for Business.
  6. The problematic situation was identified and escalated too late.

Processes and role/responsibilities division

  1. Expectations towards PM whose role was extended to acting / assisting PO were not clear at the beginning and later.
  2. No one took full ownership for PO duties such as backlog management, aligning teams to understand requirements and mutual dependancies, manage teams to deliver fully functional product etc.
  3. Data flows and architecture were not clear because of the lack of proper documentation.
  4. Client decided to proceed without a dedicated QA engineer from NG but their responsibilities were not covered by anyone else.
  5. Multiple sprints were not fully delivered because of missing backend integration or tests.
  6. NG team did not alarm about missing competences in the project.

QA

  1. There is a strong need to understand the requirements of both parties (NG and Riide) and to establish a common version of events.
  2. Misunderstanding with the client - NG team assumed the quality assurance would be provided on the client’s side.
  3. The quality assurance was not taken care of (no QA specialist assignment, nor QA's responsibilities transferred to another team member).
  4. None quality-related process was established nor included to the project management processes
  5. Quality semaphore was not warning.
  6. NG Team did not escalate the issue/risk coming from missing quality assurance of the project.

Estimations

  1. Riide for Business (the web project) was kicked off as an extension of the mobile project, thus there was:
    1. no Discovery Team engagement
    2. no workshops/scoping session
    3. no pre-sales estimations.
  2. There was a lack of in-depth analysis and specification of the functionalities that are supposed to be developed resulted in lack of documented scope, leading to lack of estimations.
  3. Later defined scope was not presented in a clear way.
  4. Changes in the scope, bugs, estimations, and all unplanned need to result in updating the project timeline.

AAR observations

  • The AAR was conducted by peer PM which we found very beneficial.
  • To address the issue with lacking context, AAR facilitator consulted the list of attendees prior to the meeting and sent them a pre-AAR survey in order to make sure all crucial topics identified by the attendees are covered.
  • PM assigned to the project could stay focus on the project and, what’s more important, take part in the AAR meeting as an attendee.
